contentrichtext.text: {{Multiple issues |refimprove = November 2011 |disputed = November 2011 }} {{For|those of a similar name|Arthur Ferguson (disambiguation)}} '''Arthur Furguson''' (1883–1938) was (or may have been) a Scottish [[con artist]] who allegedly became known for "selling" English national monuments and other government property to visiting American tourists during the 1920s. It is claimed that in the 1920s, Furguson sold monuments such as [[Nelson's Column]] in [[Trafalgar Square]] (for the sum of £6,000), [[Clock Tower, Palace of Westminster|Big Ben]] (£1,000 for a down payment), and [[Buckingham Palace]] (£2,000 for a down payment) to American tourists. Furguson emigrated to the USA in 1925. He sold the [[White House]] to a rancher on the [[hire purchase|installment plan]] for yearly payments of $100,000, and tried to sell the [[Statue of Liberty]] to a visiting Australian, who went to the police. Furguson was imprisoned and was released in 1930. He continued to defraud people in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] until his death in 1938. However, according to author Dane Love, who profiled Furguson in his book ''The Man Who Sold Nelson's Column'', the existence of Furguson himself may be a hoax. Love attempted to trace contemporary records which would confirm the story, but found "[t]here was nothing about his arrest, his trial or his time in jail in New York. There's not even any trace of his grave in Los Angeles, where he supposedly died in 1938." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sundaymail.co.uk/tv-showbiz-news/entertainment-news/2009/02/08/tv-quiz-host-stephen-fry-duped-by-story-of-fictional-scots-conman-78057-21105696/ |title=TV quiz host Stephen Fry duped by story of fictional Scots conman - The Daily Record |publisher=Sundaymail.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}}</ref> The earliest known reference to Furguson dates from as recently as the 1970s. ==See also== *[[Victor Lustig]] *[[George C.
